revision.text:
{{Eschatology}} {{Religious text primary|date=September 2015}} '''Punishment of the Grave''' ({{lang-ar|عذاب القبر}} ''ʿAdhāb al-Qabr'', also translated '''torment of the grave''') is an [[Islam|Islamic]] concept whereby in the time between [[Islamic view of death|death]] and resurrection on the [[Day of Judgement]], the souls of the unrighteous are punished in the [[Barzakh|grave]] and those of the righteous find the grave "peaceful and blessed".[[#JACBMM2014|J.A.C. Brown, ''Misquoting Muhammad'', 2014]]: p.46 According to [[Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya]], those in the grave "may be punished for their ignorance of Allah, their ignoring His commands and their disobedience towards Him".{{cite web |last1=Saalih al-Munajjid |first1=Muhammad |title=45325: Reasons for the punishment in the grave |url=https://islamqa.info/en/45325 |website=Islam Question and Answer |accessdate=26 June 2018}} Unlike most Islamic theological principles the punishment of the grave is not mentioned in the Quran "in any obvious way", but found in a [[hadith]] compiled by scholars such as [[Ibn Hanbal]].{{Cite web|url=http://quransmessage.com/articles/grave%20punishment%20FM3.htm|title=PUNISHMENT OF THE GRAVE (AZAB-E-QABR)|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} ==Punishment== According to Ibn Al-Qayyim, animals are able to hear the Punishment of the Grave while human beings cannot.''The Soul's Journey After Death'', An Abridgement of Ibn Al-Qayyim's ''Kitabar-Ruh'', Commentary by Layla Mabrouk. p.21 Some Muslims also believe that the living can intercede for the dead who are undergoing punishment, to at least temporarily halt their suffering.
Muhammad said: "After he has died, the believer only gets the benefit of the following actions and good deeds: knowledge which he has taught and passed on, a righteous son or daughter he leaves behind, a copy of the Quran which he has bequeathed, a mosque he has built, a house he has built for the traveler, a water channel he has dug, or an act of charity which he spent out of his property when he was alive and in good health and which comes to him after his death."''The Soul's Journey After Death'', An Abridgement of Ibn Al-Qayyim's ''Kitabar-Ruh'', Commentary by Layla Mabrouk. p.33
==Examples in Hadith== The [[hadith]] tradition contains numerous reports of descriptions of the punishment of the grave, its victims, their sins. This includes [[Hadith terminology#Sahih]] ("authentic") hadith by [[Muhammad al-Bukhari]] and [[Muslim ibn al-Hajjaj]]. (However, many ''[[Hadith]]'' are considered by some Islamic sects such as the [[Muʿtazila]] to be non-authenticated, due to them having a single-chain of transmission i.e. ''Ahad Hadith''). *Narrated [[`Abd Allah ibn `Abbas|Ibn 'Abbas]]: Allah's Apostle passed by two graves and said, "Both of them (persons in the grave) are being tortured, and they are not being tortured for a major sin. This one used not to save himself from being soiled with his urine, and the other used to go about with calumnies (among the people to rouse hostilities, e.g., one goes to a person and tells him that so-and-so says about him such-and-such evil things). The Prophet then asked for a green leaf of a date-palm tree, split it into two pieces and planted one on each grave and said, "It is hoped that their punishment may be abated till those two pieces of the leaf get dried."[http://muflihun.com/bukhari/73/78 Sahih al-Bukhari Vol. 8, Book 73, Hadith 78] *From [[Abu Hurayrah]] who said: The Prophet said, “When one of you finishes the last tashahhud (testimony of faith in prayer), he should seek refuge in Allah from four things: From the Punishment of Hell, from the Punishment of the Grave, from the trials of life and death, and from the evil trials of the Maseehud-Dajjaal (Anti-Christ).”Related by [[Sahih Muslim]] (2/93), Abu Daawood (no. 983), and others from Abu Hurayrah *Anas reported Mohammed as saying: If you were not (to abandon) the burying of the dead (in the grave), I would have certainly supplicated to Allah that He should make you listen to the torment of the grave.Muslim, Book 40, Hadith 6860: The Book Pertaining to Paradise, Its Description, Its Bounties and Its Intimates *Narrated [[Anas ibn Malik]]: The Prophet said, "When a human being is laid in his grave and his companions return and he even hears their footsteps, two angels come to him and make him sit and ask him: What did you use to say about this man, Muhammad ? He will say: I testify that he is Allah's servant and His Apostle. Then it will be said to him, 'Look at your place in the Hell-Fire. Allah has given you a place in Paradise instead of it. “The Prophet added, "The dead person will see both his places. But a non-believer or a hypocrite will say to the angels, 'I do not know, but I used to say what the people used to say! It will be said to him, 'Neither did you know nor did you take the guidance (by reciting the Quran).' Then he will be hit with an iron hammer between his two ears, and he will cry and that cry will be heard by whatever approaches him except human beings and jinns."Bukhari, Book 2, Volume 23, Hadith 422: Funerals * [[Umm Salama Hind bint Abi Umayya|Umm Salama]] reported: The Messenger of Allah came to Abu Salama (as he died). His eyes were fixedly open. He closed them, and then said: When the soul is taken away the sight follows it. Some of the people of his family wept and wailed. So he said: Do not supplicate for yourselves anything but good, for angels say "Amen" to what you say. He then said: O Allah, forgive Abu Salama, raise his degree among those who are rightly guided, grant him a successor in his descendants who remain. Forgive us and him, O Lord of the Universe, and make his grave spacious, and grant him light in it.Muslim, Book 4, Hadith 2003: The Book of Prayers ==See also== *[[Islamic view of death]] *[[Barzakh]] *[[Sheol]] (Judaism) ==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist|group=Note}} ===Citations=== {{Reflist|2}} ===Books, etc.=== * {{cite book|last1 = Brown|first1 = Jonathan A.C.|authorlink=Jonathan A.C. Brown |title = Misquoting Muhammad: The Challenge and Choices of Interpreting the Prophet's Legacy|date = 2014|publisher = [[Oneworld Publications]]|isbn = 978-1780744209|url=https://archive.org/stream/misquoting-muhammad-pbuh/misquoting-muhammad-pbuh_djvu.txt |accessdate=4 June 2018 |ref= JACBMM2014}} ==External links== *[http://abdurrahman.org/finaljourney/ The Death, Life After Death, The Signs of the Hour] {{Islam topics}} {{Sunni hadith literature}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Punishment Of The Grave}} [[Category:Afterlife]] [[Category:Arabic words and phrases]] [[Category:Islamic terminology]]

{{BLP sources|date=May 2010}} {{Infobox boxer |name = Richie Mepranum |realname = Richie Mepranum |nickname =''Magnum'' |height = 165cm |nationality = [[Filipino people|Filipino]] |weight = [[Flyweight]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1987|5|5|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Maasim, Sarangani|Maasim]], [[Sarangani]], [[Philippines]] |style = [[Southpaw (boxing)|Southpaw]] |total = 39 |wins = 31 |KO = 8 |losses = 7 |draws = 1 }}
'''Richie Mepranum''' (born May 5, 1987 in [[Maasim, Sarangani|Maasim]], [[Sarangani]], [[Philippines]]) is a [[Filipino people|Filipino]] professional [[Boxing|boxer]] and current WBO Oriental flyweight champion.
==Fighting style== A fine boxer and a skilled counter-puncher, Mepranum is considered one of the Philippines' best kept secrets.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://uk.asiancorrespondent.com/edwin-espejo/richie%e2%80%99s-chances-are-good | title =Richie Mepranum primed for title shot | last =Espejo | first =Edwin | work = | publisher =US-AsianCorrespondent.com | date =June 11, 2010 | accessdate =June 12, 2010}}</ref>
==Professional career==
===Flyweight=== Mepranum made his professional debut on August 31, 2005, defeating fellow Filipino boxer Leovimil Florentino by KO in Magpet, Cotabato (del Norte), Philippines.
The Filipino boxer won the WBO Oriental flyweight title on June 14, 2006 against previously unbeaten Joma Funda. The bout was held at the Maasim Gym in Maasim, Sarangani, Philippines; Mepranum won the bout by unanimous decision with the scores of 119-109, 119-109 and 120-108.
Mepranum suffered his first loss on September 14, 2007, against [[Thailand|Thai]] boxer [[Denkaosan Kaovichit]] at the Potawattana Saenee School, Ratchaburi, Thailand. Kaovichit won by unanimous decision with the scores of 116-112, 115-113, 116-112. Kaovichit became a world champion a year later, in a bout against [[Japan]]'s [[Takefumi Sakata]] for the [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] [[List of WBA world champions#Flyweight|World Flyweight]] title. He bounced back by defeating [[Rocky Fuentes]] by [[split decision]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://philboxing.com/news/story-19372.html |title=Rocky Fuentes Victorious In Bantayan |publisher=Philboxing.com |date=2008-10-06 |accessdate=2016-10-06}}</ref>
On March 12, 2010, Mepranum fought against Mexico's unbeaten [[Hernan Marquez|Hernan "Tyson" Marquez]] (27-0; 20 KO) at the Gaylord Hotel in Grapevine, Texas, United States. The Filipino boxer defeated Marquez with an impressive unanimous decision, with the scores of 99-91, 96-94, 98-92.
In June 2010, Mepranum fought for the vacant WBO Flyweight title relinquished by Argentina's [[Omar Andrés Narváez]].<ref>{{cite web | last =Nathanielsz | first =Ronnie | title =Mepranum To Fight For Vacant WBO Flyweight Belt | work = | publisher =BoxingScene.com | date =May 14, 2010 | url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=27783 | accessdate =May 14, 2010}}</ref> The Filipino boxer took on Mexico's [[Julio César Miranda]] (31-5-1; 24 KO) on June 12, 2010 at the Convention Center in Puebla, Mexico.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=28461 | title =Mepranum Ready, Healthy To Win The WBO Title | last =Nathanielsz | first =Ronnie | work = | publisher =BoxingScene.com | date =June 11, 2010 | accessdate =June 12, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=28480 | title =Mepranum, Miranda Ready To Rumble For WBO Gold | last =Nathanielsz | first =Ronnie | work = | publisher =BoxingScene.com | date =June 12, 2010 | accessdate =June 12, 2010}}</ref> Miranda was a veteran fighter with 37 fights and has fought for a world title twice which the Mexican failed to win. Mepranum was defeated by TKO in round 5 and Miranda was crowned WBO flyweight champion.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=28495 | title =Julio Cesar Miranda Stops Richie Mepranum in Five | last = | first = | work = | publisher =BoxingScene.com | date =June 13, 2010 | accessdate =June 13, 2010}}</ref> The bout did not start well for Miranda. The Mexican, however, took the pace in the next round, sending Mepranum down twice to the canvas, once in the 4th round and once in the fifth. The referee stopped the fight after the second knockdown, to avoid any more punishment.
Mepranum's next fight was held on November 13, 2010, on the undercard of the [[Pacquiao vs. Margarito]] boxing match. His opponent was Anthony Villareal, who lost to [[Milan Melindo]] in January 2010. The Sarangani native won the bout by split decision.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{boxrec|id=335594}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mepranum, Richie}} [[Category:1987 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Light-flyweight boxers]] [[Category:Flyweight boxers]] [[Category:People from Sarangani]] [[Category:Southpaw boxers]] [[Category:Filipino male boxers]]

{{Infobox SCC |case-name=Rodriguez v British Columbia (AG) |full-case-name=Sue Rodriguez v The Attorney General of Canada and the Attorney General of British Columbia |heard-date=May 20, 1993 |decided-date=September 30, 1993 |citations=[1993] 3 SCR 519, 107 DLR (4th) 342, 1993 CanLII 75 |docket= 23476 |history=On appeal from the [[Court of Appeal for British Columbia]] |subsequent= |ruling=Appeal dismissed |ratio= Criminal prohibition of assisted suicide does not violate the ''Charter''. |SCC=1992-1997 |Majority=Sopinka J |JoinMajority=La Forest, Gonthier, Iacobucci and Major JJ |Dissent=McLachlin J |JoinDissent=L'Heureux-Dubé J |Dissent2=Lamer CJ |Dissent3=Cory J |LawsApplied=''Charter of Rights and Freedoms'', s 7
''Criminal Code'', s 241(b) |Overruled=''[[Carter v Canada (AG)]]'', [https://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14637/index.do 2015 SCC 5] }}{{italic title|all=yes|noerror}} '''''Rodriguez v British Columbia (AG)''''', [1993] 3 SCR 519 is a landmark [[Supreme Court of Canada]] decision where the prohibition of [[assisted suicide]] was challenged as contrary to the ''[[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]]'' ("''Charter''") by a terminally ill woman, [[Sue Rodriguez]]. In a 5–4 decision, the Court upheld the provision in the ''[[Criminal Code (Canada)|Criminal Code]]''. ==Background== Sue Rodriguez was a 42-year-old mother whose illness [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] (ALS or "Lou Gehrig's disease") was diagnosed in 1992. By 1993, it was found that she would not live more than a year, and so she began a crusade to strike down section 241(b) of the ''Criminal Code'', which made assisted suicide illegal, to the extent it would be illegal for a terminally ill person to commit "physician-assisted" suicide. She applied to the [[Supreme Court of British Columbia]] to have section 241(b) of ''Criminal Code'' struck down because it allegedly violated [[Section Seven of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|sections 7]] (the right to "life, liberty, and security of the person), [[Section Twelve of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|12]] (protection against "cruel and unusual treatment or punishmenthttps://www.canlii.org/en/ca/scc/doc/1993/1993canlii75/1993canlii75.html") and [[Section Fifteen of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|15(1)]] of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (equality). ==Reasons of the court== Sopinka J, writing for the majority, found there was no violation of section 7. He first considered whether the prohibition on ending one's life engaged the right to [[security of person]]. He found the prohibition had sufficient connection with the justice system by its impact on an individual's autonomy and right to life by causing physical and psychological pain. However, Sopinka J found the provision did not violate any principles of fundamental justice. He examined the long history of the prohibition of suicide and concludes that it reflects part of the fundamental values of society and so could not be in violation of fundamental justice. He also rejected the claim that the provision violated the section 12 right against cruel and unusual treatment or punishment as a mere prohibition did not fall within the meaning of treatment. Lastly, he considered the section 15 equality challenge. He noted the issue is best not resolved under this right, but in assuming it did violate section 15, he found it was clearly saved under section 1. He found the objective was pressing and substantial, rational and that there was no lesser means to achieve the goal. In dissent, Lamer CJ held that the ''Criminal Code'' section 241(b) had infringed on section 15, but he did not consider sections 7 and 12. Cory J ruled that the right to die is as much a protected freedom under section 7 of the ''Charter'' as any other part of life. McLachlin J's judgment was that ''Criminal Code'' section 241(b) violated the section 7 right to security of the person and that the violation was not saved under section 1. ==Overturned== The Supreme Court's ruling in ''Rodriguez'' was overturned 22 years later in the 2015 decision in ''[[Carter v Canada (AG)]]'',2015 SCC 5. which found that denying assisted suicide in some cases violated Section 7 of the ''Charter''. ==See also== * [[List of Supreme Court of Canada cases (Lamer Court)]] * [[Suicide legislation]] * [[Euthanasia in Canada]] ==References== ==External links== *{{lexum-scc2|1993|3|519|75}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rodriguez V. British Columbia (Attorney General)}} [[Category:Section Seven Charter case law]] [[Category:Supreme Court of Canada cases]] [[Category:1993 in Canadian case law]] [[Category:Assisted suicide]] [[Category:Euthanasia law]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} [[File:PlanetaSH(3).jpg|300px|thumb|right|Artist's impression of one possible appearance of a superhabitable planet. The reddish hue is vegetation.<ref name="Plnts" />]]
A '''superhabitable planet''' is a hypothetical type of [[exoplanet]] or [[exomoon]] that may be better suited than [[Earth]] for the [[Abiogenesis|emergence]] and [[evolution]] of [[life]]. The concept was introduced in 2014 by René Heller and John Armstrong,{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=50|ps=}} who have criticized the language used in the search for [[Planetary habitability|habitable planets]], so they propose clarifications because a [[circumstellar habitable zone]] (HZ) is not enough to define a planet's habitability.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=51|ps=}} Heller and Armstrong state that it is not clear why Earth should offer the most suitable physicochemical parameters to living organisms, because "planets could be non-Earth-like, yet offer more suitable conditions for the emergence and evolution of life than Earth did or does." While still assuming that life requires water, they hypothesize that Earth may not represent the optimal [[planetary habitability]] conditions for maximum [[biodiversity]]; in other words, they define a superhabitable world as a [[Rocky planet|terrestrial planet]] or moon that could support more diverse [[flora]] and [[fauna]] than there are on Earth, as it would empirically show that its [[Environment (biophysical)|environment]] is more hospitable to life.
Heller and Armstrong also point out that not all [[rocky planet]]s in a [[circumstellar habitable zone|habitable zone]] (HZ) may be habitable, and that [[tidal heating]] can render terrestrial or icy worlds habitable beyond the stellar HZ, such as in [[Europa (moon)|Europa]]'s internal ocean.<ref name="HZ">{{cite journal| author1=Reynolds, R.T. |author2=McKay, C.P. |author3=Kasting, J.F. |title=Europa, tidally heated oceans, and habitable zones around giant planets |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0273117787903644 |journal=Advances in Space Research |pages=125–132 |issue=7 |year=1987 | doi = 10.1016/0273-1177(87)90364-4|bibcode = 1987AdSpR...7..125R }}</ref>{{#tag:ref|The habitable zone (HZ) is a region present around each star where a terrestrial planet or moon that has an atmospheric pressure and a suitable combination of gases, could maintain liquid water on its surface.<ref>{{cite journal| last=Mendez |first=Abel |date=10 August 2011 |title=Habitable Zone Distance (HZD): A habitability metric for exoplanets |journal=PHL |url=http://phl.upr.edu/library/notes/habitablezonesdistancehzdahabitabilitymetricforexoplanets |access-date=22 July 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://phl.upr.edu/projects/habitable-exoplanets-catalog/data|title=Planetary Habitability Laboratory |access-date=17 July 2015 |publisher=PHL de la [[University of Puerto Rico at Arecibo|UPRA]] |date=2 April 2015 }}</ref> However, planets in the HZ may not be habitable, as tidal heating during the planet's orbit can be an additional heat source that causes a planet to enter a runaway greenhouse state.|group=n.}} The authors propose that in order to identify a habitable—or superhabitable—planet, a characterization concept is required that is biocentric rather than geo- or [[anthropocentric]].{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=50|ps=}} Heller and Armstrong proposed to establish a profile for exoplanets according to stellar type, mass and location in their [[planetary system]], among other features. According to these authors, such superhabitable worlds would likely be larger, warmer, and older than Earth, and orbiting [[K-type main-sequence star]]s.
== General characteristics == Heller and Armstrong proposed that a series of basic characteristics are required to classify an [[exoplanet]] or [[exomoon]] as superhabitable;<ref>{{cite news |last=Choi |first=Charles Q. |url=http://www.astrobio.net/news-exclusive/super-habitable-world-may-exist-near-earth/ |title=Super-Habitable World May Exist Near Earth |work=Astrobiology Magazine |date=March 14, 2014 |accessdate=2016-04-01 }}</ref>{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=50|ps=}}<ref>{{cite journal| author=Williams, D.M. |author2=Kasting, J.F. |title=Habitable Planets with High Obliquities |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103597957596 |journal=Icarus |pages=254–267 |issue=1 | date=September 1997 |doi=10.1006/icar.1997.5759 |bibcode=1997Icar..129..254W}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| author=Rushby, A.J. |author2=Claire, M.W. |author3=Osborn, H. |author4=Watson, A.J. |title=Habitable Zone Lifetimes of Exoplanets around Main Sequence |url=http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/ast.2012.0938 |journal=Astrobiology |pages=833–849 |issue=13 |date=18 September 2013}}</ref> {{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=59|ps=}} for size, it is required to be about 2 [[mass of the Earth|Earth masses]], and 1.3 [[Earth radius|Earth radii]] will provide an optimal size for [[plate tectonics]].{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55|ps=}} In addition, it would have a greater [[gravity|gravitational attraction]] that would increase retention of gases during the planet's formation.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=59|ps=}} It is therefore likely that they have a denser [[atmosphere]] that will offer greater concentration of [[oxygen]] and [[greenhouse gas]]es, which in turn raise the average temperature to optimum levels for plant life to about {{convert|25|C|F}}.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55-58|ps=}}<ref name="ScAm">{{cite web |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/podcast/episode/superhabitable-planets/ |title=Faraway Planets May Be Far Better for Life |access-date=20 April 2015 |last=Moyer |first=Michael |date=31 January 2014 |journal=Scientific American }}</ref> A denser atmosphere may also influence the surface relief, making it more regular and decreasing the size of the [[ocean basin]]s, which would improve diversity of marine life in shallow waters.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=54-56|ps=}}
Other factors to consider are the [[Stellar classification|type of star]] in the system. [[K-type star]]s are less massive than the Sun, and are stable on the main sequence for a very long time (15 to 30 billion years, compared to 10 billion for the Sun, a [[Stellar classification#Class G|G-class star]]),{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=57|ps=}}{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=56-57|ps=}} giving more time for the [[Abiogenesis|emergence of life]] and [[evolution]]. A superhabitable world would also require to be located near the center of the [[Circumstellar habitable zone|habitable zone]] of its star system for a long time.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=56|ps=}}{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=54-59|ps=}}
=== Surface, size and composition ===
[[File:Relative sizes of all of the habitable-zone planets discovered to date alongside Earth.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Kepler-62e]], second from the left has a radius of 1.6 R<sub>⊕</sub>. Earth is on the far right; scaled.]] An exoplanet with a larger volume than that of Earth, or with a more complex [[terrain]], or with a larger surface covered with liquid water, could be more hospitable for life than Earth.<ref>{{cite book| last=Pierrehumbert| first=Raymond T.| title=Principles of Planetary Climate| url=http://www.cambridge.org/gb/academic/subjects/earth-and-environmental-science/climatology-and-climate-change/principles-planetary-climate?format=HB| publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521865562}}</ref> Since the volume of a planet tends to be directly related to its mass, the more massive it is, the greater its gravitational pull, which can result in a denser atmosphere.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://phl.upr.edu/library/notes/habitablezoneatmospherehzaahabitabilitymetricforexoplanets| title=Habitable Zone Atmosphere |access-date=16 July 2015 |first=[[PHL]] |work=PHL University of Puerto Rico at Arecibo }}</ref>
Some studies indicate that there is a natural limit, set at 1.6R<sub>⊕</sub>, below which nearly all planets are [[terrestrial planet|terrestrial]], composed primarily of rock-iron-water mixtures.<ref>{{cite news| title=How to make a planet just like Earth |url=http://news.sciencemag.org/space/2015/01/how-make-planet-just-earth| last=Clery |first=Daniel |journal=Science Magazine|date=5 January 2015| access-date=16 April 2015}}</ref> Generally, objects with a mass below 6 [[Earth mass|M<sub>⊕</sub>]] are very likely to be of similar composition as Earth.<ref>{{cite news| title=New Instrument Reveals Recipe for Other Earths |url=http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/news/2015-03 |journal=Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics| date=5 January 2015| access-date=16 April 2015}}</ref> Above this limit, the density of the planets decreases with increasing size, the planet will become a [[Ocean planet|"water world"]] and finally a [[gas giant]].<ref>{{cite news| title=What Makes an Earth-Like Planet? Here's the Recipe |url=http://www.space.com/28312-earth-like-planets-recipe.html |journal=Space.com| date=21 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| last=Rogers |first=Leslie A. |year=2015 |title=Most 1.6 Earth-radius Planets are Not Rocky |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |volume=801 |issue=1 |pages=41 |doi=10.1088/0004-637X/801/1/41 |url=http://iopscience.iop.org/0004-637X/801/1/41/ |arxiv=1407.4457 |access-date=5 August 2015 |bibcode=2015ApJ...801...41R}}</ref> In addition, most [[super-Earth]]s' high mass may cause them to lack [[plate tectonics]].{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55|ps=}} Thus, it is expected that any exoplanet similar to Earth's density and with a radius under 1.6 R<sub>⊕</sub> may be suitable for life.<ref name="ScAm" /> However, other studies indicate that water worlds represent a transitional stage between [[mini-Neptune]]s and the terrestrial planets, especially if they belong to [[red dwarf]]s or [[K-type star|K dwarfs]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.space.com/28535-red-dwarf-planet-life.html |title=Planets Orbiting Red Dwarfs May Stay Wet Enough for Life |access-date=23 April 2015 |last=Choi |first=Charles Q. |date=17 February 2015 |publisher=Space.com }}</ref><ref name="WW">{{cite news| first=Elizabeth |last=Howell |title=Kepler-62f: A Possible Water World |url=http://www.space.com/24142-kepler-62f.html |journal=Space.com |date=2 January 2014 |access-date=21 April 2015 }}</ref> Although water planets may be habitable, the average depth of the water and the absence of land area would not make them superhabitable as defined by Heller and Armstrong.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=54|ps=}} From a geological perspective, the optimal mass of a planet is about 2 M<sub>⊕</sub>, so it must have a [[radius]] that keeps the density of the [[Earth]] among 1.2 and 1.3R<sub>⊕</sub>.<ref name="REth">{{cite news| author=Noack, L. |author2=Breuer, D. |title=Plate Tectonics on Earth-like Planets |bibcode=2011epsc.conf..890N | journal=EPSC Abstracts |pages=890–891 |issue=6 |year=2011}}</ref>
The average depth of the oceans also affects the habitability of a planet. The shallow areas of the sea, given the amount of light and heat they receive, usually are more comfortable for aquatic species, so it is likely that exoplanets with a lower average depth are more suitable for life.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=54|ps=}}<ref>{{cite news| first=John S. |last=Gray |title=Marine biodiversity: patterns, threats, and conservation needs |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023%2FA%3A1018335901847 |journal=Biodiversity & Conservation |pages=153–175 |issue=6 |year=1997}}</ref> More massive exoplanets would tend to have a regular surface gravity, which can mean shallower—and more hospitable—ocean basins.<ref>{{cite news| title=Super-Earth Planets May Have Watery Earthlike Climates |url=http://www.space.com/24216-super-earth-exoplanets-earthlike-climate-aas223.html |last=Lewis |first=Tanya |journal=Space.com| date=9 January 2014| access-date=16 April 2015}}</ref>
=== Geology === [[Plate tectonics]], in combination with the presence of large bodies of water on a planet, is able to maintain high levels of [[carbon dioxide]] ({{chem|C|O|2}}) in its atmosphere.<ref>{{cite journal| first1=Douwe G. |last1=Van Der Meer |first2=Richard E. |last2=Zeebe |first3=Douwe J. J. |last3=van Hinsbergen |first4=Appy |last4=Sluijs |first5=Wim |last5=Spakman |first6=Trond H. |last6=Torsvik |title=Plate tectonic controls on atmospheric CO2 levels since the Triassic |journal=PNAS |volume=111 |issue=12 |pages=4380–4385 |date=25 March 2014 |pmc=3970481 |pmid=24616495 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1315657111|bibcode = 2014PNAS..111.4380V }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title=Climate change: How do we know? |url=https://climate.nasa.gov/evidence/ |author=NASA| access-date=19 April 2015}}</ref> This process appears to be common in geologically active terrestrial planets with a significant rotation speed.<ref>{{cite journal| author=Riguzzi, F. |author2=Panza, G. |author3=Varga, P. |author4=Doglioni, C. |title=Can Earth's rotation and tidal despinning drive plate tectonics? |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0040195109003321 |journal=Tectonophysics |pages=60–73 |volume=484 |issue=1 |date=19 March 2010 |doi=10.1016/j.tecto.2009.06.012|bibcode = 2010Tectp.484...60R }}</ref> The more massive a planetary body, the longer time it will generate internal heat, which is a major contributing factor to plate tectonics.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55|ps=}} However, excessive mass can also slow plate tectonics because of increased pressure and viscosity of the mantle, which hinders the sliding of the [[lithosphere]].{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55|ps=}} Research suggests that plate tectonics peaks in activity in bodies with a mass between 1 and 5M<sub>⊕</sub>, with an optimum mass of approximately 2M<sub>⊕</sub>.<ref name="REth" />
If the geological activity is not strong enough to generate a sufficient amount of greenhouse gases to increase global temperatures above the freezing point of water, the planet could experience a permanent [[ice age]], unless the process is offset by an intense internal heat source such as [[tidal heating]] or stellar irradiation.<ref>{{cite news| author=Walker, J.C.G. |author2=Hays, P.B. |author3=Kasting, J.F. |title=A negative feedback mechanism for the long-term stabilization of the earth's surface temperature |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/JC086iC10p09776/abstract;jsessionid=7C2466400356F88A3A66F1D12E0F083B.f03t01 |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |pages=9776–9782 |issue=86 |year=1981}}</ref>
===Magnetosphere=== Another feature favorable to life is a planet's potential to develop a strong [[magnetosphere]] to protect its surface and atmosphere from [[cosmic radiation]] and [[Solar wind|stellar winds]], especially around [[Habitability of red dwarf systems|red dwarf stars]].<ref>{{cite news| author=Baumstark-Khan, C. |author2=Facius, R. |title=Life under conditions of ionizing radiation |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/JC086iC10p09776/abstract;jsessionid=7C2466400356F88A3A66F1D12E0F083B.f03t01 |journal=Astrobiology |pages=261–284 |year=2002}}</ref> Less massive bodies and those with a slow rotation, or those that are [[tidal locking|tidally locked]], have a weak or no magnetic field, which over time can result in the loss of a significant portion of its atmosphere, especially [[hydrogen]], by [[hydrodynamic escape]].{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55|ps=}} [[File:Mangrove-1.JPG|thumb|240px|right|The climate of a warmer and wetter terrestrial exoplanet may resemble that of the [[Tropics|tropical]] regions of Earth. In the picture, [[mangrove]] in [[Cambodia]].]]
=== Temperature and climate === The optimum temperature for Earth-like life in general is unknown, although it appears that on Earth organism diversity has been greater in warmer periods.<ref>{{cite news| author1=Mayhew, P.J. |author2=Bell, M.A. |author3=Benton, T.G. |author4=McGowan, A.J. |title=Biodiversity tracks temperature over time |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/109/38/15141 |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |pages=15141–15145 |issue=38 |volume=109 |year=2012|bibcode = 2012PNAS..10915141M |doi = 10.1073/pnas.1200844109 }}</ref> It is therefore possible that exoplanets with slightly higher average temperatures than that of Earth are more suitable for life.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55-56|ps=}} The thermoregulatory effect of large oceans on exoplanets located in a habitable zone may maintain a moderate temperature range.<ref>{{cite news| first=Ian |last=O'Neill |title=Oceans Make Exoplanets Stable for Alien Life |url=http://news.discovery.com/space/alien-life-exoplanets/oceans-make-exoplanets-stable-for-alien-life-140721.htm |journal=Discovery News |date=21 July 2014 |access-date=21 April 2015 }}</ref>{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55-56|ps=}} In this case, deserts would be more limited in area and would likely support habitat-rich coastal environments.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55-56|ps=}}
However, studies suggest that Earth already lies near to the inner edge of the habitable zone of the [[Solar System]],<ref>{{cite news| author1=Kopparapu, R.K. |author2=Ramirez, R. |author3=Kasting, J. |author4=Eymet, V. |title=Habitable Zones Around Main-Sequence Stars: New Estimates |url=http://iopscience.iop.org/0004-637X/765/2/131/ |journal=Astrophysical Journal |page=131 |issue=2 |volume=765 |year=2013|arxiv = 1301.6674 |bibcode = 2013ApJ...765..131K |doi = 10.1088/0004-637X/765/2/131 }}</ref> and that may harm its long-term livability as the luminosities of main-sequence stars steadily increase over time, pushing the habitable zone outwards.{{Sfn|Perryman|2011|p=283-284|ps=}}<ref>{{cite news| first=Fraser |last=Cain |title=How Long Will Life Survive on Earth? |url=http://www.universetoday.com/25367/how-long-will-life-survive-on-earth/ |journal=Universe Today |date=30 September 2013 |access-date=22 April 2015 }}</ref> Therefore, superhabitable exoplanets must be warmer than Earth, yet orbit further out than Earth does and closer to the center of the system's [[habitable zone]].<ref name="PHLHZD">{{cite news| first=Abel |last=Mendez |title=Habitable Zone Distance (HZD): A habitability metric for exoplanets |url=http://phl.upr.edu/library/notes/habitablezonesdistancehzdahabitabilitymetricforexoplanets |journal=PHL |date=30 July 2012 |access-date=22 April 2015 }}</ref>{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=56|ps=}} This would be possible with a thicker atmosphere or with a higher concentration of [[greenhouse gas]]es.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=58|ps=}}{{Sfn|Perryman|2011|p=269|ps=}}
=== Star === [[File:HZD2.jpg|thumb|left|260px|[[Habitable zone]] (HZ) position of some of the most [[Earth Similarity Index|similar]] and average surface temperature exoplanets.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://phl.upr.edu/projects/habitable-exoplanets-catalog/results |title=HEC: Graphical Catalog Results |access-date=24 April 2015 |author=PHL }}</ref>{{#tag:ref|The initials "HZD" or "Habitable Zone Distance" mark the position of a planet about the center of the habitable zone of the system (value 0). A negative HZD value means that the orbit of a planet is smaller near its star —the center of the habitable zone— while a positive value means a wider orbit around its star. The values 1 and -1 mark the boundary of the habitable zone.<ref name="PHLHZD" /> A superhabitable planet should have a HZD of 0 (the optimal location within the habitable zone).{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=56|ps=}}|group=n.}}]] The [[stellar classification|star's type]] largely determines the conditions present in a system.<ref name="RDrf">{{cite web| last=Schirber |first=Michael |title=Can Life Thrive Around a Red Dwarf Star?| url=http://www.space.com/6560-life-thrive-red-dwarf-star.html| publisher=Space.com| date=9 April 2009| access-date=17 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=Binary Star Systems: Classification and Evolution| url=http://www.space.com/22509-binary-stars.html|publisher=Space.com|date=23 August 2013| access-date=17 April 2015}}</ref> The most massive stars O, B, and A have a very short life cycle, quickly leaving the [[main sequence]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=how-do-scientists-determi| title=How do scientists determine the ages of stars? Is the technique really accurate enough to use it to verify the age of the universe?| access-date=11 May 2007| date=13 July 2006| publisher=Scientific American| first1=S. A.| first2=P. B.| last1=Naftilan| last2=Stetson}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Laughlin | first1=G. | last2=Bodenheimer | first2=P. | last3=Adams | first3=F. C. | title=The End of the Main Sequence | journal=The Astrophysical Journal | date=1997 | volume=482 | issue=1 | pages=420–432 | bibcode=1997ApJ...482..420L | doi = 10.1086/304125}}</ref> In addition, O and B type stars produce a [[photoevaporation]] effect that prevents the [[accretion (astrophysics)|accretion]] of planets around the star.<ref>{{cite news| first=David |last=Dickinson |title="Death Stars" Caught Blasting Proto-Planets |url=http://www.universetoday.com/110271/death-stars-caught-blasting-proto-planets/ |journal=Universe Today |date=13 March 2014 |access-date=21 April 2015}}</ref>{{Sfn|Perryman|2011|p=285|ps=}}
On the opposite side, the less massive [[Red dwarf|M]] and [[K-type star|K]] types are by far the most common and long-lived stars of the universe, but their potential for supporting life is still under study.<ref name="RDrf" />{{Sfn|Perryman|2011|p=285|ps=}} Their low luminosity reduces the size of the [[habitable zone]], which are exposed to ultraviolet radiation outbreaks that occur frequently, especially during their first billion year of existence.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=57|ps=}} When a planet's orbit is too short, it can cause [[tidal locking]] of the planet, where it always presents the same hemisphere to the star, known as ''day hemisphere''.<ref>{{cite news| first=Nola T. |last=Redd |title=Tidal Locking Could Render Habitable Planets Inhospitable |url=http://www.astrobio.net/news-exclusive/tidal-locking-could-render-habitable-planets-inhospitable/ |journal=Astrobiology |date=8 December 2011 |access-date=21 April 2015 }}</ref>{{Sfn|Perryman|2011|p=285|ps=}} Even if the existence of life were possible in a system of this type, it is unlikely that any exoplanet belonging to a [[red dwarf]] star would be considered superhabitable.<ref name="RDrf" />
Dismissing both ends, systems with a [[K-type star]]s offer the best habitable zones for life.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=57|ps=}}{{Sfn|Perryman|2011|p=285|ps=}} K-type stars allow the formation of planets around them, have a long life expectancy, and provide a stable habitable zone free of the effects of excessive proximity to its star.{{Sfn|Perryman|2011|p=285|ps=}} Furthermore, the radiation produced by a K-type star is high enough to allow complex life without the need for an atmospheric [[ozone layer]].{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=57|ps=}}<ref>{{cite journal|author=Cockell, C.S. |title=Carbon Biochemistry and the Ultraviolet Radiation Environments of F, G, and K Main Sequence Stars |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103599961675 |journal=Icarus |pages=399–407 |issue=2 |volume=141 | date=October 1999 |doi=10.1006/icar.1999.6167 |bibcode=1999Icar..141..399C}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Rushby, A.J. |author2=Claire, M.W. |author3=Osborn, H. |author4=Watson, A.J. |title=Habitable Zone Lifetimes of Exoplanets around Main Sequence |url=http://iopscience.iop.org/0004-637X/765/2/131/ |journal=Astrobiology |pages=833–849 |issue=9 |volume=13 |year=2013|bibcode = 2013AsBio..13..833R |doi = 10.1089/ast.2012.0938 }}</ref> They are also the most stable and their habitable zone does not move very much during its lifetime, so a terrestrial analog located near a K-type star may be habitable for almost all of the main sequence.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=57|ps=}}
=== Orbit and rotation === [[File:Kepler186f-ArtistConcept-20140417.jpg|350px|thumb|right|Artistic impression of a possible [[Earth analog]], [[Kepler-186f]]. Some superhabitable planets could have a similar appearance and may not have important differences with Earth.]]
Experts have not reached a consensus about what is the optimal rotation speed for an exoplanet, but it should not be too fast nor too slow. The latter case can cause some problems similar to those observed in Venus, which completes one rotation every 243 Earth days and as a result, cannot generate an Earth-like [[magnetic field]].<ref>{{cite news| first=Charles Q. |last=Choi |title=Planet Venus Facts: A Hot, Hellish & Volcanic Planet |url=http://www.space.com/44-venus-second-planet-from-the-sun-brightest-planet-in-solar-system.html |journal=Space.com |date=4 November 2014 |access-date=2 August 2015 }}</ref>{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=57-58|ps=}}
Ideally, the orbit of a superhabitable world must be at the midpoint of the habitable zone of its [[star system]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.space.com/23910-habitable-zones-alien-planets-stars-infographic.html |title=How Habitable Zones for Alien Planets and Stars Work |access-date=20 April 2015 |last=Tate |first=Karl |date=11 December 2013}}</ref>{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=58|ps=}}
=== Atmosphere === There are no solid arguments to explain if Earth's atmosphere has the optimal composition to host life.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=58|ps=}} On Earth, during the period when [[coal]] was first formed, atmospheric oxygen ({{chem|O|2}}) levels were up to 35%, and coincided with the periods of greatest [[biodiversity]].<ref>{{cite book| author=Falcon-Lang, H. J.| title=Fire ecology of a Late Carboniferous floodplain, Joggins, Nova Scotia| year=1999| publisher=Journal of the Geological Society| location=London| chapter=156| pages=137–148}}</ref> So, assuming that the presence of a significant amount of oxygen in the atmosphere is essential for exoplanets to develop complex life forms,<ref>{{cite news| author1=Harrison, J.F. |author2=Kaiser, A. |author3=VandenBrooks, J.M. |title=Atmospheric oxygen level and the evolution of insect body size |url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/277/1690/1937 |journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B |pages=1937–1946 |volume=277 |date=26 May 2010}}</ref>{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=58|ps=}} the percentage of oxygen relative to the total atmosphere appears to limit the maximum size of the planet for optimum superhabitability and ample biodiversity{{Clarify|date=October 2016}}.
Also, the atmospheric density should be higher in more massive planets, which reinforces the hypothesis that [[super-Earths]] can provide superhabitable conditions.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=58|ps=}}
=== Age === [[File:Artist’s Impression of a Baby Star Still Surrounded by a Protoplanetary Disc.jpg|280px|thumb|right|The first stars that formed in the universe were [[metallicity|metal-free stars]], which probably prevented planet formation.]] In a biological context, older planets than Earth may have greater biodiversity, since native species have had more time to [[Biological evolution|evolve]], adapt and stabilize the environmental conditions to sustain a suitable environment for life that can benefit their descendants.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=56-57|ps=}}
However, for many years it was thought that since older star systems have lower [[metallicity]], they should display low planet formation, and thus such old planets may have been scant in the beginning,<ref>{{cite news| first=Ray |last=Sanders |title=When Stellar Metallicity Sparks Planet Formation |url=http://www.astrobio.net/news-exclusive/when-stellar-metallicity-sparks-planet-formation/ |journal=Astrobiology Magazine |date=9 April 2012 |access-date=7 August 2015 }}</ref> but the number of ''[[Metallicity|metallic]]'' items in the universe must have grown steadily since its inception.<ref name="AgP">{{cite news| url=http://www.space.com/17441-universe-heavy-metals-planet-formation.html |title=When Did the Universe Have the Right Stuff for Planets? |access-date=24 April 2015 |journal=Space.com |last=Cooper |first=Keith |date=4 September 2012}}</ref> The first exoplanetary discoveries, mostly gas giants orbiting very close to their stars, known as ''[[Hot Jupiters]]'', suggest that planets were rare in systems with low metallicity, which invited suspicion of a time limit on the appearance of the first objects landmass.{{Sfn|Perryman|2011|p=188-189|ps=}} Later, in 2012, the [[Kepler (spacecraft)|Kepler telescope]]'s observations allowed experts to find out that this relationship is much more restrictive in systems with [[Hot Jupiters]], and that terrestrial planets could form in stars of much lower metallicity, to some extent.<ref name="AgP" /> It is now thought that the first Earth-mass objects should appear sometime between 7 and 12 billion years.<ref name="AgP" /> Given the greater stability of the orange dwarfs (K-type) compared to the Sun (G-type) and longer life expectancy, it is possible that superhabitable exoplanets belonging to K-type stars, orbiting within its habitable zone, could provide a longer, steadier, and better environment for life than Earth.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=57|ps=}}
== Profile summary == [[File:Kepler442b(comp).jpg|240px|thumb|right|A size comparison and artist's impression of Kepler-442b (1.34 R<sub>⊕</sub>) to the [[Earth]] (right).]] Despite the scarcity of information available, the hypotheses presented above on superhabitable planets can be summarized as a preliminary profile, even if there is no scientific consensus.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=59|ps=}} * Mass: approximately 2M<sub>⊕</sub>. * Radius: to maintain a similar Earth density, its radius should be between 1.2 and 1.3R<sub>⊕</sub>. * Oceans: percentage of surface area covered by oceans should be Earth-like but more distributed, without large continuous land masses. The oceans should be shallow; the light then will penetrate easier through the water and will reach the fauna and flora, stimulating an abundance of life down in the ocean. * Distance: shorter distance from the center of the habitable zone of the system than Earth. * Temperature: average surface temperature of about {{convert|25|C|F}}.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55-58|ps=}} * Star and age: belonging to an intermediate [[K-type star]] with an older age than the Sun (4.5 billion years) but younger than 7 billion years. * Atmosphere: somewhat denser than Earth's and with a higher concentration of oxygen. That will make life larger and more abundant.
There is no confirmed exoplanet that meets all these requirements. After updating the database of exoplanets on 23 July 2015, the one that comes closest is [[Kepler-442b]], belonging to an orange dwarf star, with a radius of 1.34R<sub>⊕</sub> and a mass of 2.34M<sub>⊕</sub>, but with an estimated surface temperature of {{convert|-2.65|C|F}}.<ref name="NASA">{{cite web |url=http://exoplanetarchive.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/DisplayOverview/nph-DisplayOverview?objname=Kepler-442+b| title=NASA Exoplanet Archive |access-date=8 January 2015 |first=[[NASA]] |work=NASA Exoplanet Science Institute }}</ref><ref name="PHL">{{cite web |url=http://phl.upr.edu/projects/habitable-exoplanets-catalog/data|title=Planetary Habitability Laboratory |access-date=7 January 2015 |first=[[PHL]] |work=PHL University of Puerto Rico at Arecibo }}</ref>
=== Appearance ===
The appearance of a superhabitable planet should be, in general, very similar to Earth.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=54-59|ps=}} The main differences, in compliance with the profile seen previously, would be derived from its mass. Its denser atmosphere probably prevent the formation of ice sheets as a result of lower thermal difference between different regions of the planet.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=58|ps=}} Also, it has a higher concentration of clouds, and abundant rainfall.
Probably the vegetation is very different due to the increased air density, precipitation, temperature, and stellar flux. For the type of light emitted from the [[K-type star]]s, plants may take other colors than green.<ref name="Plnts">{{cite journal| journal=Scientific American| author=Nancy Y. Kiang| date=April 2008| title=The color of plants on other worlds| url=http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?id=the-color-of-plants-on-other-worlds| access-date=2 March 2015| doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0408-48| volume=298| pages=48–55|bibcode = 2008SciAm.298d..48K }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.space.com/3680-colorful-worlds-plants-planets-green.html |title=Colorful Worlds: Plants on Other Planets Might Not Be Green |access-date=2 March 2015 |last=Than |first=Ker |date=11 April 2007 }}</ref> The vegetation would cover more regions than vegetation here on Earth, making this visible from space.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=54-59|ps=}}
In general, the climate of a superhabitable planet would be warmer, moist, homogeneous and have stable land, allowing life to extend across the surface without presenting large population differences, in contrast to Earth that has inhospitable areas such as glaciers, deserts and tropical regions.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55-56|ps=}} If the atmosphere contains enough molecular oxygen, the conditions of these planets may be bearable to humans even without the protection of a [[space suit]], provided that the atmosphere does not contain excessive toxic gases, but would require some adaptation to the increased gravity, such as an increase in muscles and in bone density, etc.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=54-59|ps=}}<ref name="WW" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.space.com/20728-new-alien-planets-oceans-life.html |title=What Might Alien Life Look Like on New 'Water World' Planets? |access-date=23 April 2015 |last=Wall |first=Mike |date=18 April 2013 |publisher=Space.com }}</ref>
== Abundance == [[File:SH Planet comp.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Set and subsets of terrestrial worlds.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=61|ps=}}]] Heller and Armstrong speculate that the number of superhabitable planets can far exceed that of [[Earth analog]]s:{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=61|ps=}} less massive stars in the [[main sequence]] are more abundant than the larger and brighter stars, so there are more orange dwarfs than solar analogues.<ref>{{cite journal| last=LeDrew |first=Glenn |year=2001 |title=The Real Starry Sky |journal=Journal of the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada |volume=95 |issue=686 |pages=32–33 |issn=0035-872X |url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-iarticle_query?2001JRASC..95...32L&data_type=PDF_HIGH&whole_paper=YES&type=PRINTER&filetype=.pdf |format=PDF |access-date=16 July 2015 |bibcode=2001JRASC..95...32L}}</ref> It is estimated that about 9% of stars in the Milky Way are [[K-type star]]s.<ref>{{cite book| last=Croswell |first=Ken |title=Planet Quest: The Epic Discovery of Alien Solar Systems |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=60sPD6yjbVAC&pg=PA84&lpg=PA84&dq=percentage+%22orange+dwarfs%22+milky+way&source=bl&ots=Zit9UpfGA-&sig=o1ASitJqAFJH7NqnlVOyRS-DLsU&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAWoVChMI0_Ki-cjgxgIVxVoUCh3AYACT#v=onepage&q=percentage%20%22orange%20dwarfs%22%20milky%20way&f=false |access-date=17 July 2015 |edition=1 |year=1997 |publisher=Free Press |isbn=0684832526 |page=84 }}</ref>
Another point favoring the predominance of superhabitable planets in regard to Earth analogs is that, unlike the latter, most of the requirements of a superhabitable world can occur spontaneously and jointly simply by having a higher mass.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=54-58|ps=}} A planetary body close to 2 or 3M<sub>⊕</sub> should have longer-lasting plate tectonics and also will have a larger surface area in comparison to Earth.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=59|ps=}} Similarly, it is likely that its oceans are shallower by the effect of gravity on the planet's crust, its gravitational field more intense and, a denser atmosphere.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=55-58|ps=}}
By contrast, Earth-mass planets may have a wider range of conditions. For example, some may sustain active tectonics for a shorter time period and will therefore end up with lower air density than Earth, increasing the probability of developing global ice coverage, or even a permanent [[Snowball Earth]] scenario.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=58|ps=}} Another negative effect of lower atmospheric density can be manifested in the form of thermal oscillations, which can lead to high variability in the global climate and increase the chance for catastrophic events. In addition, by having a weaker [[magnetosphere]], such planets may lose their atmospheric hydrogen by [[hydrodynamic escape]] easier and become a desert planet.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=58|ps=}} Any of these examples could prevent the emergence of life on a planet's surface.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/ames/kepler/nasas-kepler-discovers-first-earth-size-planet-in-the-habitable-zone-of-another-star/#.VMlrZi4XeOU |title=NASA's Kepler Discovers First Earth-Size Planet In The 'Habitable Zone' of Another Star |access-date=4 August 2015 |last1=Johnson |first1=Michele |last2=Harrington |first2=J.D. |date=17 April 2014 |publisher=NASA }}</ref> In any case, the multitude of scenarios that can turn an Earth-mass planet located in the habitable zone of a solar analogue into an inhospitable place are less likely on a planet that meets the basic features of a superhabitable world, so that the latter should be more common.{{Sfn|Heller|Armstrong|2014|p=61|ps=}}

{{Orphan|date=May 2015}}
'''The Seven Pillars of Life''' are the essential principles of [[life]] described by [[Daniel E. Koshland, Jr.|Daniel E. Koshland]] in 2002 in order to create a universal definition of life.<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/news/science/biology/2002-03-29-life-pillars.htm</ref> One stated goal of this universal definition is to aid in understanding and identifying [[artificial life|artificial]] and [[extraterrestrial life]].<ref>Koshland D. E. Jr (2002). The Seven Pillars of Life. Science, 295: 2215-2216</ref> The seven pillars are Program, Improvisation, Compartmentalization, Energy, Regeneration, Adaptability, and Seclusion. These can be abbreviated as PICERAS.
== The Seven Pillars ==
=== Program === Koshland defines "Program" as an "organized plan that describes both the ingredients themselves and the kinetics of the interactions among ingredients as the living system persists through time."<ref>Koshland D. E. Jr (2002). The Seven Pillars of Life. Science, 295: 2215-2216</ref> In natural life as it is known on Earth, the program operates through the mechanisms of [[nucleic acids]] and [[amino acids]], but the concept of program can apply to other imagined or undiscovered mechanisms.
=== Improvisation === "Improvisation" refers to the living system's ability to change its program in response to the larger [[Environment (biophysical)|environment]] in which it exists. An example of improvisation on earth is [[natural selection]].
=== Compartmentalization === "Compartmentalization" refers to the separation of spaces in the living system that allow for separate environments for necessary chemical processes. Compartmentalization is necessary to protect the concentration of the ingredients for a reaction from outside environments.
=== Energy === Because living systems involve net movement in terms of chemical movement or body movement, and lose energy in those movements through [[entropy]], [[energy]] is required for a living system to exist. The main source of energy on Earth is the sun, but other sources of energy exist for life on Earth, such as hydrogen gas or methane, used in [[chemosynthesis]].
=== Regeneration === "Regeneration" in a living system refers to the general compensation for losses and degradation in the various components and processes in the system. This covers the thermodynamic loss in chemical reactions, the wear and tear of larger parts, and the larger decline of components of the system in [[ageing]]. Living systems replace these losses by importing molecules from the outside environment, synthesizing new molecules and components, or creating new generations to start the system over again.
=== Adaptability === "Adaptability" is the ability of a living system to respond to needs, dangers, or changes. It is distinguished from improvisation because the response is timely and does not involve a change of the program. Adaptability occurs from a molecular level to a behavioral level through [[feedback]] and [[Feedforward neural network|feedforward]] systems. For example, an animal seeing a predator will respond to the danger with hormonal changes and escape behavior.
=== Seclusion ===
== Criticism == Y. N. Zhuravlev and V. A. Avetisov have analyzed Koshland's seven pillars from the context of [[primordial life]] and, though calling the concept "elegant," point out that the pillars of compartmentalization, program, and seclusion don't apply well to the non-differentiated earliest life.<ref>Zhuravlev, Y. N. and V. A. Avetisov."The definition of life in the context of its origin"''[[Biogeosciences]]'', 2006-07-10. Retrieved on 2008-08-09.</ref>

[[File:The Principles and practice of gynecology - for students and practitioners (1904) (14581562657).jpg|thumb|A 1904 gynecology textbook that describes some vaginal anomalies.]] '''Vaginal anomalies''' are [[Birth defect#Terminology|abnormal structures]] that are formed (or not formed) during the prenatal development of the female reproductive system and are rare congenital defects that result in an abnormal or absent vagina.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/pediatrics/congenital-renal-and-genitourinary-anomalies/vaginal-anomalies|title=Vaginal Anomalies - Pediatrics - Merck Manuals Professional Edition|work=Merck Manuals Professional Edition|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US}}</ref> When present, they are often found with uterine, skeletal and urinary abnormalities.<ref name= emed2>{{cite journal|date=2016-06-01|title=Mullerian Duct Anomalies: Overview, Incidence and Prevalence, Embryology|url=https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/273534-overview#a4}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/pediatrics/congenital-renal-and-genitourinary-anomalies/vaginal-anomalies|title=Vaginal Anomalies - Pediatrics - Merck Manuals Professional Edition|work=Merck Manuals Professional Edition|access-date=2018-01-06|language=en-US}}</ref> This is because these structures, like the vagina, are most susceptible to disruption during crucial times of organ-genesis. Many of these defects are classified under the broader term [[Mullerian anomalies|Mullerian duct anomalies]].<ref name="emed2"/><!--there are two emed references that are very similar but not equivalent, bpage--><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/pediatrics/congenital-renal-and-genitourinary-anomalies/vaginal-anomalies|title=Vaginal Anomalies-Pediatrics-Merck Manuals Professional Edition|access-date=2018-01-06}}</ref> Mullerian duct anomalies are caused by a disturbance during the embryonic time of genitourinary development.<ref name="emed1">{{cite web|url=https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/273534-overview|title=Mullerian Duct Anomalies: Overview, Incidence and Prevalence, Embryology|date=2016-06-01}}</ref> The other isolated incidents of vaginal anomalies can occur with no apparent cause. Oftentimes vaginal anomalies are part of a cluster of defects or syndromes. In addition, [[Inheritance of acquired characteristics|inheritance]] can play a part as can prenatal exposure to some [[teratogens]].<ref name="emed2" /><ref>The most notable teratogen that is strongly associated with vaginal anomalies is the synthetic hormone [[Diethylstilbestrol]]</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">The inheritance patterns of some vaginal anomalies can be [[autosomal dominant]], [[autosomal recessive]], and [[X-linked disorders]].</ref><ref name = emed3>{{cite web|date=2017-05-04|title=Imperforate Hymen: Background, Problem, Epidemiology|url=https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/269050-overview#a8}}</ref> Many vaginal anomalies are not detected at birth because the external genitalia appear to be normal.<ref name="emed2" /> Other organs of the [[reproductive system]] may not be affected by an abnormality of the vagina. The uterus, [[fallopian tube]]s and ovaries can be functional despite the presence of a defect of the vagina and external genitalia.<ref name=emed2/> A vaginal anomaly may not affect fertility. Though it depends on the extent of the vaginal defect, it is possible for [[fertilisation|conception]] to occur. In instances where a functional ovary exists, [[In vitro fertilisation|IVF]] may be successful. Functioning ovaries in a woman with a vaginal defect allows the implantation of a fertilized ovum into the uterus of an unaffected gestational carrier. A successful conception and can occur.<ref name = "Altchek_2009">{{cite journal | vauthors = Altchek A, Paciuc J | title = Successful pregnancy following surgery in the obstructed uterus in a uterus didelphys with unilateral distal vaginal agenesis and ipsilateral renal agenesis: case report and literature review | journal = Journal of Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology | volume = 22 | issue = 5 | pages = e159-62 | date = October 2009 | pmid = 19576808 | doi = 10.1016/j.jpag.2009.02.001 }}</ref><ref name="emed2" /> Vaginal length varies from 6.5 to 12.5 cm. Since this is slightly shorter than older descriptions, it may impact the diagnosis of women with vaginal agenesis or hypoplasia who may unnecessarily be encouraged to undergo treatment to increase the size of the vagina.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lloyd J, Crouch NS, Minto CL, Liao LM, Creighton SM | title = Female genital appearance: "normality" unfolds | journal = Bjog | volume = 112 | issue = 5 | pages = 643–6 | date = May 2005 | pmid = 15842291 | doi = 10.1111/j.1471-0528.2004.00517.x }}</ref> Vaginal anomalies may cause difficulties in urination, conception, pregnancy, impair sex. Psychosocial effects can also exist.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/pediatrics/congenital-renal-and-genitourinary-anomalies/overview-of-congenital-genitourinary-anomalies|title=Overview of Congenital Genitourinary Anomalies - Pediatrics - Merck Manuals Professional Edition|work=Merck Manuals Professional Edition|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Signs and symptoms ==
===Isolated anomalies=== Some anomalies are found upon examination shortly after birth or when the development of sexual characteristics does not progress as expected. Defects that prevent menstrual flow become obvious when amenorrhea occurs.
=== Syndromes === Syndromes may take longer to identify since they are rare and often involve errors in metabolism. Many syndromes share the same signs and symptoms.
== Cause == The cause of isolated cases of vaginal anomalies can not always be identified, though disruption of the embryonic development of the vagina likely plays a significant role.
== Diagnosis == Imaging studies are usually the most useful in diagnosing vaginal anomalies including retrograde contrast studies.<ref name=":2" /> An [[anomaly scan]] can be helpful, especially detecting the presence of a urogenital syndrome. Genetic and metabolic defects require further testing to support a diagnosis.
== Treatment == [[File:Double vagina Vagina duplex from Golay 1875.png|thumb|upright=1.25|1875 illustration of the presence of two vaginas]] Vaginal anomalies are treated surgically.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Dietrich JE, Millar DM, Quint EH | title = Obstructive reproductive tract anomalies | language = English | journal = Journal of Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology | volume = 27 | issue = 6 | pages = 396–402 | date = December 2014 | pmid = 25438708 | doi = 10.1016/j.jpag.2014.09.001 | url = http://www.jpagonline.org/article/S1083-3188(14)00314-3/fulltext }}</ref> A 'neo-vagina' can be constructed for those girls and women who do not have a vagina.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.atlasofpelvicsurgery.com/2VaginalandUrethra/22SigmoidNeovagina/chap2sec22.html | title = Sigmoid Neovagina | work = Atlas of Pelvic Surgery | access-date=2018-01-31 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.atlasofpelvicsurgery.com/2VaginalandUrethra/13McIndoeVaginoplastyforNeovagina/chap2sec13.html | title = McIndoe Vaginoplasty for Neovagina | work = Atlas of Pelvic Surgery | access-date = 2018-01-31 }}</ref> Vaginal septa are treated surgically.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.atlasofpelvicsurgery.com/2VaginalandUrethra/6ExcisionofTransverseVaginalSeptum/chap2sec6.html |title=Excision of Transverse Vaginal Septum | work = Atlas of Pelvic Surgery | access-date = 2018-01-31 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.atlasofpelvicsurgery.com/2VaginalandUrethra/7CorrectionofDouble-BarreledVagina/chap2sec7.html | title = Correction of Double-Barreled Vagina | work = Atlas of Pelvic Surgery | access-date = 2018-01-31}}</ref>
The most common vaginal anomaly is an [[imperforate hymen]]. This anomaly occurs often enough that it can be detected by some pediatricians shortly after birth. Correction of an imperforate hymen may delayed until puberty. The hymen can be unusually thick or partially obstructed by the presence of fibrous bands of [[connective tissue|tissue]]. An imperforate hymen can also present with other abnormalities such as septa. An imperforate hymen can be displaced and its location may not be where it is expected. Other abnormalities of the hymen can exist including the presence of septa, displacement and a hymen that consists of microperforations.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/269050-overview |title=Imperforate Hymen: Background, Problem, Epidemiology|date=2017-05-04}}</ref><ref name="Acién_2016">{{cite journal | vauthors = Acién P, Acién M | title = The presentation and management of complex female genital malformations | journal = Human Reproduction Update | volume = 22 | issue = 1 | pages = 48–69 | date = 2016-01-01 | pmid = 26537987 | doi = 10.1093/humupd/dmv048 }}</ref> Uncommonly, a double hymen is present.<ref name="emedicine.medscape.com">{{cite journal|date=2017-12-06|title=Amenorrhea: Background, Pathophysiology, Etiology|url=https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/252928-overview}}</ref><ref name="Coran">{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QpabASTwF_sC&pg=PA1599 | title = Pediatric Surgery | vauthors = Coran AG, Caldamone A, Adzick N, Krummel T, Laberge J, Shamberger R | publisher = [[Elsevier Health Sciences]] | year = 2012 | isbn = 978-0-323-09161-9 | page = 1599 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lardenoije C, Aardenburg R, Mertens H | title = Imperforate hymen: a cause of abdominal pain in female adolescents | journal = BMJ Case Reports | volume = 2009 | date = 2009-05-26 | pmid = 21686660 | pmc = 3029536 | doi = 10.1136/bcr.08.2008.0722 }}</ref> The imperforate hymen is treated by excision and drainage. Sometimes a small border of hymenal tissue is left around the opening of the vagina.<ref>{{Cite book |title=State-of-the-art : vaginal surgery |last=Goel |first=Neerja |last2=Rajaram |first2=Shalini |last3=Mehta |first3=Sumita |year=2013 |isbn=9789350902875 |edition=2nd |location=New Delhi |page=6 |oclc=858649878}}</ref>
[[Congenital adrenal hyperplasia]] can cause the abnormal development of the vagina.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wang LC, Poppas DP | title = Surgical outcomes and complications of reconstructive surgery in the female congenital adrenal hyperplasia patient: What every endocrinologist should know | journal = The Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology | volume = 165 | issue = Pt A | pages = 137–144 | date = January 2017 | pmid = 26995108 | doi = 10.1016/j.jsbmb.2016.03.021 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0960076016300681 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|date=2017-02-21|title=Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia: Practice Essentials, Background, Pathophysiology|url=https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/919218-overview}}</ref><!--<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cain|first=MarkPatrick|last2=Rink|first2=RichardCarlos|last3=Leslie|first3=JeffreyA|date=2009-01-01|title=Feminizing genital reconstruction in congenital adrenal hyperplasia|url=http://www.indianjurol.com/text.asp?2009/25/1/17/45532|journal=Indian Journal of Urology|volume=25|issue=1|doi=10.4103/0970-1591.45532}}</ref>--><ref>{{cite web|url=https://medlineplus.gov/ency/article/001497.htm|title=Developmental disorders of the female genital tract | work = MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia | access-date = 2018-01-29 }}</ref> [[Vaginal adenosis]] is the abnormal presence of cervical and uterine tissue within the wall of the vagina.<ref name="Laronda_2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Laronda MM, Unno K, Butler LM, Kurita T | title = The development of cervical and vaginal adenosis as a result of diethylstilbestrol exposure in utero | journal = Differentiation; Research in Biological Diversity | volume = 84 | issue = 3 | pages = 252–60 | date = October 2012 | pmid = 22682699 | doi = 10.1016/j.diff.2012.05.004 | pmc = 3443265 }}</ref> Ten percent of women have this condition and remain unsymptomatic. It rarely develops into a malignancy.<ref name="Kranl1998">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kranl C, Zelger B, Kofler H, Heim K, Sepp N, Fritsch P | title = Vulval and vaginal adenosis | journal = The British Journal of Dermatology | volume = 139 | issue = 1 | pages = 128–31 | date = July 1998 | pmid = 9764164 }}</ref> [[Cloacal exstrophy]] is a condition when two vaginas are present.<ref name="medline97">{{cite web | url = https://medlineplus.gov/ency/article/001497.htm | title = Developmental disorders of the female genital tract | work = MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia | access-date = 2018-01-21 }}</ref><ref name="UCF_Cloacal_Exstrophy">{{cite web | url = https://www.urologyhealth.org/urologic-conditions/cloacal-exstrophy | work = Urology Care Foundation | title = What is Cloacal Exstrophy? | access-date = 2018-01-20 }}</ref><ref name="Biason-Lauber_2007">{{cite journal | vauthors = Biason-Lauber A, De Filippo G, Konrad D, Scarano G, Nazzaro A, Schoenle EJ | title = WNT4 deficiency--a clinical phenotype distinct from the classic Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome: a case report | journal = Human Reproduction | volume = 22 | issue = 1 | pages = 224–9 | date = January 2007 | pmid = 16959810 | doi = 10.1093/humrep/del360 }}</ref> [[Vaginal agenesis]] or the complete absence of the vagina affects 1 out of 5,000 women.<ref name="UCF_Vaginal_Agenesis">{{cite web | url = http://www.urologyhealth.org/urologic-conditions/vaginal-abnormalities-vaginal-agenesis | work = Urology Care Foundation | title = What is Vaginal Agenesis? | access-date = 2018-01-21 }}</ref> A hemivagina is the abnormal presence of a partial vagina that is attached to the wall of the functioning vagina. The hemivagina does not open to the normal vagina and is attached to an abnormal, second uterus.<ref name="Jindal_2009">{{cite journal | vauthors = Jindal G, Kachhawa S, Meena GL, Dhakar G | title = Uterus didelphys with unilateral obstructed hemivagina with hematometrocolpos and hematosalpinx with ipsilateral renal agenesis | journal = Journal of Human Reproductive Sciences | volume = 2 | issue = 2 | pages = 87–9 | date = July 2009 | pmid = 19881156 | pmc = 2800935 | doi = 10.4103/0974-1208.57230 }}</ref> [[Vaginal hypoplasia]] is the under-development of the vagina and is found in instances of [[complete androgen insensitivity syndrome]].<ref name="González" /><ref name="Callens2014" /><ref name="pennmed">{{cite web | url = https://www.pennmedicine.org/for-patients-and-visitors/patient-information/conditions-treated-a-to-z/mullerian-anomalies | title = Mullerian Anomalies | work = Penn Medicine | access-date = 2018-01-21 }}</ref> [[Vaginal septum|Vaginal septa]] are structures consisting of fibrous tissue that block the vagina.<ref name="medline97" /><ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QpabASTwF_sC&pg=PA1599#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Pediatric Surgery E-Book | vauthors = Coran AG, Caldamone A, Adzick N, Krummel T, Laberge J, Shamberger R|date=2012-01-25|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences | isbn = 978-0-323-09161-9 }}</ref> The tissue extends horizontally, blocking or partially blocking the vaginal canal or transversly essentially creating two vaginas that connect to a normal uterus.<ref name="Heinonen_2006">{{cite journal | vauthors = Heinonen PK | title = Complete septate uterus with longitudinal vaginal septum | journal = Fertility and Sterility | volume = 85 | issue = 3 | pages = 700–5 | date = March 2006 | pmid = 16500341 | doi = 10.1016/j.fertnstert.2005.08.039 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Perez-Brayfield MR, Clarke HS, Pattaras JG | title = Complete bladder, urethral, and vaginal duplication in a 50-year-old woman | journal = Urology | volume = 60 | issue = 3 | page = 514 | date = September 2002 | pmid = 12350504 | doi = 10.1016/S0090-4295(02)01808-3 }}</ref> Septa can prevent menstrual flow and result in painful intercourse, though some women do not have symptoms.<ref name="Pfeifer_2016">{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=7TyVDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA43&dq=%22vaginal+anomalies%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjKx8LwlvDYAhVNSK0KHQNmCH0Q6AEILDAA#v=onepage&q=%22vaginal%20anomalies%22&f=false | title = Congenital Müllerian Anomalies: Diagnosis and Management | vauthors = Pfeifer S | date = 2016-06-30 | publisher = Springer | isbn = 978-3-319-27231-3 | page = 3 }}</ref><ref name="González" /><ref name="Heinonen_2006" /> Many vaginal anomalies are not detected at birth because the external genitalia can appear to be normal.<ref name="emed2" />

==Anomalies associated with syndromes== Some congenital syndromes present with vaginal anomalies in association with other serious conditions. These include [[Fraser syndrome]], [[WNT4 deficiency]], and [[Bardet–Biedl syndrome|Bardet-Biedl]] syndrome,<ref name="pennmed" /><!--<ref name="Chattopadhyay" /></ref>--><ref>{{cite web|url=https://rarediseases.org/rare-diseases/wnt4-deficiency/|title=WNT4 Deficiency - NORD (National Organization for Rare Disorders)|work=NORD (National Organization for Rare Disorders)|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-22}}</ref><ref name = "Slavotinek_2002" /><ref name = "NLM_MCA/MR" /> Isolated incidents of vaginal anomalies can occur with no apparent cause and in other instances these anomalies are part of a [[syndrome]] or cluster of other abnormalities. The origin of many vaginal anomalies is due to a disturbance during the [[Embryonic Anomaly|embryonic]] stage of [[Genitourinary system|genitourinary]] development.<ref name="emed1" /> Inheritance can play a part as can prenatal exposure to [[hormone]]<nowiki/>s and [[teratogens]].<ref name="emed2" /><ref name="ReferenceA"/> Though the presence of a vaginal anomaly does not necessarily prevent conception and a successful pregnancy when a functional uterus and ovaries are present, vaginal anomalies increase the risk of miscarriage.<ref name = "Acién_2016" /><ref name = "Altchek_2009" /><ref name="emed2" /> {| class="wikitable" |+ !Syndrome !Incidence !Acronyms !Occurs with !Notes !References |- |[[Fraser syndrome]] | | | | |<ref name = pennmed/><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = François | first1 = Jules | name-list-format = vanc | title = Syndrome malformatif avec cryptophtalmie | journal = Ophthalmologica | date = 1965 | volume = 150 | issue = 3 | pages = 215–218 | doi = 10.1159/000304848 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Francannet C, Lefrançois P, Dechelotte P, Robert E, Malpuech G, Robert JM | title = Fraser syndrome with renal agenesis in two consanguineous Turkish families | journal = American Journal of Medical Genetics | volume = 36 | issue = 4 | pages = 477–9 | date = August 1990 | pmid = 2389805 | doi = 10.1002/ajmg.1320360421 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = van Haelst MM, Scambler PJ, Hennekam RC | title = Fraser syndrome: a clinical study of 59 cases and evaluation of diagnostic criteria | journal = American Journal of Medical Genetics.
